item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Checking for 0 and 1 instead of != spam is faster.

item.title: Ticket #6071 (register_sidebars should allow name to be an array) updated
item.dc:creator: AaronCampbell
item.description:
Honestly, I've never used the ID option there, so I guess I overlooked it. I suppose we could either accept another array that we assume is in the same order as the name, or we could accept an array of arrays, each one containing name, id, etc.

It seems like it might be even easier to push more of the processing to register_sidebar(). For example, if there is only one sidebar, why aren't we passing it straight to sidebar? If there is more than one to add, it seems like we should check if $args is an array of string or an array of arrays. If it's an array of strings, we should call register_sidebar($args) $number times. If it's an array of arrays, then we should loop through $args, calling register_sidebar() for each, either using the [0] index for any extras (for example, $args contains 4 arrays, but 5 sidebars were requested to be added), or passing nothing to register_sidebar(), letting it use the defaults.

item.title: savequeries_check.diff attached to Ticket #6764
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #6764 (WPDB SAVEQUERIES unusable by plugins) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
Currently, WPDB's SAVEQUERIES constant is defined as "false" when the WPDB class file is included, if it's not already defined. That means that you can't save queries outside of defining SAVEQUERIES in wp-config.php. So plugins, for example, cannot set it to true for troubleshooting purposes.

My patch, instead of defining SAVEQUERIES on load, checks that it's defined at the two spots in which it's used.

item.title: Ticket #6745 (2.5: white screen when inserting image in post) updated
item.dc:creator: windansea
item.description:
Hi,

The exact circumstances are that I can upload the images, which are 'crunched' normally. Although I see in IE6 the uploaded images 'behind' the others when I click on show (the others do not get down). I'm logged in with 'administrator' rights. When I want to insert an image, nothing happens. The flash screen turns white and Internet Explore gives a (javascript?) error left lower corner:

line 12 char 3 Error: object doesn't support this property or method Code: 0 URL: absolute url/wp-admin/post-new.php

What other details could be usefull?

Thanks

Bert

item.title: Ticket #6763 (wp-admin/includes/dashboard.php fails due to syntax error) created
item.dc:creator: christianthheim
item.description:
[17-Apr-2008 23:13:25] PHP Parse error: syntax error, unexpected T_IF in /var/www/blog/wp-admin/includes/dashboard.php on line 8

svn annotate tells me this:

7722 ryan $widget_options = get_option( 'dashboard_widget_options' )

7722 ryan if ( !$widget_options
!is_array($widget_options) )

Basically, line 7 is missing the trailing ";"

item.title: Ticket #6761 (tinymce pop up functions fail under ssl) closed
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
invalid:

What is your setting in "WordPress address" (not "Blog Address")? All your URLs look like this: 

https:///wp-admin/post.php?...

that means you probably haven't set it.

The baseurl setting for TinyMCE is derived from your "WordPress address" setting, so it would fail if that's not set. If your LAMP wasn't on localhost, you wouldn't be able to access the site too.

Closing as invalid for now, if the same happens after WordPress is set up properly, feel free to reopen it.

item.title: Ticket #6410 (DB_COLLATE is not used in database queries) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Replying to DD32:

doesn't this mean db_collate is actually used?

"SET NAMES 'utf8'" sets the charset to utf8
"SET NAMES 'utf8' COLLATE 'abcde'" sets the charset to utf8 AND the collate to abcde(I'm not sure of a valid collate, so i'm just using that as an example)

This is correct. Collation is rarely needed unless the db charset has many possible collations.

item.title: upload_no_subdirs.patch attached to Ticket #6762
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description: Amend upload_no_subdirs to allow it to return without date sub directories by passing an argument

item.title: Ticket #6762 (Would be useful for wp_upload_dir to be able to return without date ...) created
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description:
I'm writing a plugin which needs to cache certain web readable files (CSS & JS, etc). The obvious writable directory is wp-content/uploads/, however to work out the filesystem path and web path for this dir is not easy, because wp_upload_dir always returns with the date based subdirs. I could remove the subdirs from the paths afterwards, but this seems needlessly hard.

The attached patch adds an additional argument to wp_upload_dir which requires the function to return the dirs without the date subdirs. The argument defaults to false to maintain backwards compatibility.

item.title: Ticket #6761 (tinymce pop up functions fail under ssl) updated
item.dc:creator: kirblam
item.description: Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #6761 (tinymce pop up functions fail under ssl) created
item.dc:creator: kirblam
item.description:
Using Wordpress 2.5 on a LAMP setup, applied changesets up to 7680 to see whether that helped, but still failed.

Tinymce will show up in WP 2.5 however, clicking the Image button, Charmap - anything that requires a popup - fails under ssl. From what I can tell, the baseURL isn't set properly in editor_template.js. At least, if I hard code the https address in editor_template in a particular mce function, the window renders properly.

For example: 

url:'https://<server + directory>/wp-includes/js/tinymce/themes/advanced/charmap.htm'
a

s opposed to 

url:tinymce.baseURL+'/themes/advanced/charmap.htm'

The former works, the latter produces bugs detailed below.

Screenshots should tell the whole story.

Tinymce in https environment: ​http://www.kirbymixedmedia.com/images/Picture2.png

Charmap button clicked - popup blank. Firebug notes 2 errors in lower right ​http://www.kirbymixedmedia.com/images/Picture3.png

Firebug's account of the problems:

  1. "uncaught exception: permission to denied get property Window.tinymce"
  2. This.params has no properties - tiny_mce_popup.js (line 47)

​http://www.kirbymixedmedia.com/images/Picture4.png

If I right-click in the popup itself and say "Show only this frame", the URL isn't ssl based: ​http://www.kirbymixedmedia.com/images/Picture5.png

Thanks for the explanation - it all makes sense now.

item.title: Ticket #6758 (Trac does not send email alerts to bug reports as they are updated.) created
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
I am logged in, I have my settings to have an email address. When a reply is posted to any of my trac posts, I never am notified by email. I do get emails to the posts I post, but someone replying to me, is lost for some reason.

I have looked at my email server, nothing is being blocked.

Is there an RSS feed, or at least, how can I locate all posts made by my account?

item.title: Ticket #6744 (Include upgrade warnings in a read me or other notification system) updated
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
I understand what you are saying. The reality is that of the large install base you have, 99% of those users are not going to use the avenues you outlined above. I am a developer myself, and I did not look at Peter's site, I only recently found out about the mail lists as a result of minor revolt in the forums.

The problem is the Dashboard just says, hey, you are out of date, update now, and do I did. So do thousands of others a day.

People do read readme files. I am not asking for ALL changes to be put in the read me file, but only those that change core past behavior, and can break functionality people rely on. I am in the -1 camp above, and I was not even aware of the stuff you mentioned.

Further, I spent 3+ hours in the code, trying to debug the <!--more--> issue, and in all my google searches and forum posts, no one was able to help me, it was not until I hit trac up that I found out what was going on.

By all means, do not waste time bullet pointing every change, but a read me should be included, that hypotehitically would list items such as this:

Version 2.5 changes and warnings: RSS feeds no longer truncate on <!--more--> Default main page sort order has been reversed Comments no longer support RSS feeds etc etc

you get the idea, I am talking large grand changes, that people who use wordpress in a way to support advertisers or other arrangements, where a change can cost them revenues or integrity with partners.

  • The above are examples, I am not saying WP would ever make such changes.

Point me to a place where I can glean this data, an I will be happy to maintain a concise list.

item.title: Ticket #6715 (Hitting publish button got error then going to HTML mode made post ...) updated
item.dc:creator: cyndin
item.description: Please also see: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/6757 Where I get the same disasterous bug when attempting a manual save.

item.title: Ticket #6757 (Doing a manual save causes all content in post to disappear forever) created
item.dc:creator: cyndin
item.description:
This is related to this bug: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/6715

In trying to redo my lost post (from going into HTML mode), I inserted 2 photos and typed some text. I hit "save" and got the "are you sure you want to navigate away from this page" popup. I cancelled but got it when I tried again. So I cut and paste my post into Word as a backup and then came back to WP and hit "okay."

My text and pictures went away. Gone. Into the ether. Just like with the other bug.

I have successfully done manual saves in 2.5 before. I don't know why I'm getting a false navigation popup or why I lose my post body content but not the title, cats, tags, etc.

Wordpress has become completely unusable now.

item.description: Currently the media library table has a column called "description", which uses a value from the caption field. This patch corrects the column header from "description" to "caption".

item.title: Ticket #6715 (Hitting publish button got error then going to HTML mode made post ...) updated
item.dc:creator: cyndin
item.description:
Severity changed

Please somebody make this a priority. It just happened again. I spent half an hour writing a post then clicked on "HTML" to clean up the code and the post disappeared!! I didn't have a saved copy this time. I can not believe this could happen. It never happened in older versions of WP.

You know how you get your first auto-save after you type the title then click on the body of the post? Well that's what it reverts to. The title is saved, along with the original slug (before my edit) and any other changes (category, author, tags) I made before putting in the title. Since I write the title first, there is no text. None.

I even went to the shell where my blog resides and searched for drafts. I don't know what else to do. Honestly, I'm practically in tears. This is so awful I want to switch blog software or at least go back to 2.3 (which was buggy but worked).

Do not tell me I should save my drafts manually. I never had to in 2.3 and earlier so I'm not used to it, and I didn't do anything, I just went to look at the HTML. Plus I have auto-save set to save every 2 minutes. And saving drafts puts you into a different window and you have to click on the edit post again to go back. There is no more "save and continue editing" like before. Someone on a WP board complained that that feature was gone and someone else laughed and said that's what the auto-save is for. Well, it's no good if it doesn't work.

This should not happen. Please fix this.

item.title: Ticket #6755 (backtrace improvement for wpdb) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
currently, the get_caller() method in wpdb delivers $caller = $tracefunction?;

could we change this to something that includes the class as well?

e.g. (not sure this works): 

$caller = $trace['class'] ? ( $trace['class'] . '::' . $trace['function'] ) : $trace['function'];

item.title: Ticket #6410 (DB_COLLATE is not used in database queries) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy

when SAVEQUERIES is turned on, the first query always is: 

[0]=>
  array(3) {
    [0]=>
    string(16) "SET NAMES 'utf8'"
    [1]=>
    float(0.00020217895507812)
    [2]=>
    string(12) "require_once"

doesn't this mean db_collate is actually used?

D.

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description: Okay, how about the second patch? I guess there really isn't a great advantage to including the database password anyways: if you can get the file modified time, you can probably read wp-config.php anyways.

item.title: better_wp_salt_prefix2.diff attached to Ticket #6754
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: I'd rather not introduce DB_PASSWORD into cookie key creation in any way. Best to avoid any possibility of DB_PASSWORD being brute forced. Can we make do with just mtime and only use it in the recipe only if SECRET_KEY is not defined? An admin might not want to expire cookies for everyone whenever wp-config.php is changed. I certainly wouldn't want that on wordpress.com.

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Clever solution. At first glance this seems like a good bet.

item.title: better_wp_salt_prefix.diff attached to Ticket #6754
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
As pointed out ​here, if someone gets the salt from db and SECRET_KEY is default or blank, the password security is no better off than it was in 2.3.3.

My patch adds a md5 hash of the time wp-config.php was last modified and the database password, as a prefix to the secret key. Neither should be available just from obtaining a database dump, and particularly the time wp-config.php was last modified should be difficult to determine, so that should reduce the effectiveness of such an attack as described above.

item.title: Ticket #6753 (Autosave changes draft post's author) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:
Autosave is changing the draft post's author when another user makes changes.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Create and save a draft post with user1
  2. Logout
  3. Login with user2
  4. Edit the draft
  5. Wait for autosave
  6. Go back to Manage->Posts and see the author has changed

Tested using r7693.

item.title: Ticket #6751 (wp_mime_type_icon() no longer supports custom media icons) created
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Support for custom media icons, as described ​here, has been gutted from wp_mime_type_icon(). The crystal icons are hard coded.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS (to add finding this ticket)

from ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Media_Icons

Wordpress uses media icons to represent attachment files on your blog and in the Admin interface, if those icons are available.

It looks for image files named by media type in the images directory of the current theme.

For example, for an attachment of MIME type audio/mpeg, Wordpress would look for an icon file at these locations, stopping after the first match (see wp_mime_type_icon):

item.title: Ticket #6750 (Changing User Roles Removes Role) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:

If you create a new user, the user is created without a role.

Tested on 2 different installs of r7693 with a user account set as Administrator.

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
further investigation leads me to identify get_permalink() as the likely culprit for the insane number of queries.

brings me to a thought: isn't reasonable to assume that, if at one point another a page gets queried, there's a 99% change that get_permalink() will get called? if so, it would make sense to get all the ancestors and their details whenever they're not in the cache already.

D.

item.title: Ticket #6737 (TinyMCE converts relative links incorrectly (adds wp-admin)) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Another possibility: Hook it to a setting. The "WordPress should correct invalidly nested XHTML automatically" seems to apply here. If they have that turned off, then it would not adjust the urls at all. If they have it turned on, it would make them absolute.

Regardless of that, the document base needs to be set to make it work correctly. As it stands now, that's causing the wp-admin insertion resulting in invalid links most of the time.

Patch attached. Not sure if it works properly though, it needs testing and feedback.

item.title: Ticket #6748 (wp_list_pages can cause huge numbers of SQL queries) created
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Report here: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/167000?replies=18#post-732526

Summary: wp_list_pages makes use of the Walker_Page class. Walker_Page calls get_page() which calls get_post() which calls _get_post_ancestors() which is not cached.

On a large set of pages, the _get_post_ancestors() function being called this often can result in a huge amount of queries to the database, all taking this form: SELECT post_parent FROM wp_posts WHERE ID= 'page_id' LIMIT 1

When you have nested pages in a large hierarchy, this rapidly grows obscene in terms of the number of queries performed, since it must execute one query to track each page back to the root of the hierarchy.

Example: /pageroot/ /pageroot/1/ /pageroot/1/2/ /pageroot/1/3/ /pageroot/1/4/

Doing a wp_list_pages on the above set of pages results in 12 separate queries to the database, just to get post_parents. Adding just one more subpage, like /pageroot/1/2/5/ will add 4 more queries.

Problems reported in the support forum have gotten up to 2000+ queries from one call to wp_list_pages.

item.title: Ticket #6747 (function maybe_create_table() declared in two files) created
item.dc:creator: mastermind
item.description:
The function maybe_create_table() is a nice helper for plugins that need to create a database table. As it is not available by default, one has to include the file which contains this function. So far so good.

However, maybe_create_table() is declared in /wp-admin/install-helper.php as well as in /wp-admin/includes/upgrade.php.

If, as a matter of coincidence, both of the above files are loaded, then this will of course throw a "Fatal error: Cannot redeclare maybe_create_table() in /var/www/htdocs/elnl.zirona.de/wp-admin/includes/upgrade.php on line 735"

This is not only theoretical, but I actually encountered this in the following situation:

A plugin of mine uses a function activate_plugin(), called via register_activation_hook(__FILE__, 'activate_plugin');. That function loads /wp-admin/install-helper.php to use the function maybe_create_table(). When I tried to import content to the blog (Manage -> Import -> WordPress), the page would die with the Fatal error.

The solution was to temporarily deactivate the table creating routine from the activation function.

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
figures for a site with 90 static pages:

@ init hook: 7 queries - 0.160 seconds @ template_redirect hook: 11 queries - 0.183 seconds @ wp_footer hook: 153 queries - 0.403 seconds

the 153 queries (almost all related to _get_post_ancestors()) take as much as a second every now and then...

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description: It seems there's a reason for not doing so, but when your site has a hundred static pages, displaying the pages widget readily takes a second or more...

item.title: Ticket #6744 (Include upgrade warnings in a read me or other notification system) updated
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
Type changed

The development blog does try to inform users of most changes. But, it is quite a job to describe ALL the changes to functionality in a release, especially for major releases such as 2.5. Some features, changes, and bug fixes, just get lost in the glitz of all the other 'stuff'.

During the development cycle it is helpful to read ​Peter Westwood and his weekly digest of changes made to WordPress trunk.

Belonging to the ​Trac email list is useful for keeping up with all the Trac activity. Subscribers to that email list saw several emails in February about the behavior change to 'the more' in feeds (Ticket: #2582).

For the interested users, belonging to the ​Testers email list, and the ​Hackers email list, can provide a continuing glimpse of what's happening on 'the development scene.'

In the past, in Codex, a huge effort went into documenting the new features with each release. Lloyd Budd, in particular, spent quite a bit of time fleshing out the details for ​Version 2.3. There is a ​Version 2.6 article that will need some love. Hopefully, someone will take ownership of that article and expand it as features are added or changed.

Conclusion: -1 for adding a readme file to the distribution. The development blog just feels like the best place for this kind of information. Users that would, or could, access a readme file, are likely the same users that follow the community email lists.

item.title: Ticket #6677 (JS is horribly inefficient on Write -> Post/Link pages when lots of ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description: Can we make, via a plugin or whatnot, some easy method of keeping the "All Categories" the default? I hate the most-used view and never use it.

item.title: Ticket #6745 (2.5: white screen when inserting image in post) created
item.dc:creator: windansea
item.description:
Hi,

I followed and tried all the suggestions 1-9 in the sticky 'image media uploader problem' forumtopic by 'Otto42'.

Only the final step is missing: I cannot insert the image in the post. The screen turns white and nothing happens (IE6 and Firefox/2.0.0.13. Seeing more posts about this problem, I'm no exception this time.

But what is missing is a fix, explanation or way to search to find the solution.

Thanks!

item.title: Ticket #6600 (error in function gallery_shortcode (wp-includes/media.php)) updated
item.dc:creator: noledge
item.description:
Replying to mhubi:

i have the exact same problem on the same platform (debian 4.0, php 5.2) i had PHP4 first when i upgraded to WP2.5, which worked fine. after upgrading to PHP5, no gallerys were shown in posts, and the same mysql error was drawn into the logs. the above workaround fixed this for me, though i have no idea why this worked in PHP4.

item.title: Ticket #6744 (Include upgrade warnings in a read me or other notification system) created
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
The main point of my issue at ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/6680 went largely ignored.

Wordpress needs some method of alerting users before upgrading of what changes have been made that may effect their install. I was fully unaware that a change had been made to how the <!--more--> tag works in regards to RSS feeds. I rely on RSS feeds for my advertisers. Updating to 2.5 truncated my posts at a hard coded limit, or I had to show full feeds.

While this can be fixed with a plug-in now, I would have solved that pre-upgrade, had I only known.

A changelog is too verbose for the casual user. Expecting users to search trac is asking too much of casual users.

If functionality is removed, or changed, from a past version, that users rely on, there should be clear warnings in a file in the download archive.

item.title: Ticket #6743 (preview button in admin no longer performs a save before previewing) created
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
Pre 2.5, clicking the preview button in the admin interface would also save the post. If you preview a post before the scheduled auto-save kicks in, you will not see your changes in the preview page.

Prior to version 2.5, clicking preview would first save the page, then show you an up to date preview.

item.title: 6742.patch attached to Ticket #6742
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond

item.title: Ticket #6742 (Add hook for translating English) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
I want to be able to make __('foo') return bar, even if the blog is in English. If WordPress is in any other language besides English, I think you can just use the "gettext" filter to do this. However, my blog is in English, so you can't.

Attached patch adds a backwards compatible pre-translating hook for allowing plugins to switch phrases before they are translated.

It also passes the domain to "gettext" filter for the hell of it.

item.dc:creator: ryan

item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Strip slashes before preparing link for insert. see #6644

item.title: Ticket #6709 (Usability changes to write post and write page panels) updated
item.dc:creator: jabecker
item.description:
P.S. re: ​#6635, it does not include the change to display the list of drafts at the top.

The reason that I find that function so helpful is because otherwise from the write page, I can't even tell I have drafts saved. With the way that auto-save works now, I ended up with several drafts that I had never intended creating. I realized they were there because I say it on the dashboard. But I don't go to the dashboard very often. I found it really annoying to have to go over to a separate list to find and delete the extraneous drafts. The list is really helpful information.

item.title: Ticket #6709 (Usability changes to write post and write page panels) updated
item.dc:creator: jabecker
item.description:
I'm using my own changes and have found the layout much preferable to the new WP 2.5 layout.

The Category drop-down lists either all categories or most used categories already. I don't have a ton of categories, true, but there is room at the side to list them. And I can always close the menu when I'm done selecting the categories I want.

I am also using the plugin Simple Tags. It includes tag lists and tag suggestions. The tag lists appear in a scrollable box below the tag input. Again, there's plenty of room for the box to extend down quite a ways before it needs to start scrolling, and I can close the menu when I'm finished with tags.

Don't get me wrong - I'd love to have automatic tag suggestions. But I don't see why that requires a wider area than what's available in the sidebar.

item.title: Ticket #6709 (Usability changes to write post and write page panels) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Keywords changed

If i recall correctly,

It has been said elsewhere that for now the layout of the post screens will not be changing dramatically, specifically, not moving the categories & tags to the sidepanel.

It was suggested that once the category suggestion stuff and tag suggestions were added in, the extra width of having it below the post window would make sense

But take it with a grain of salt, I dont have anything to reference off right now and i cant seem to search anything up(But i'm sure theres been at least 2 other tickets for this). I'm sure if a large enough need was wanted to move to the sidebar again it'll be considered.

Personally I do not have enough space in my sidebar for the categories, and find that the extra width under the post box is ideal.

See also: #6635

item.title: Ticket #6741 (in_category not working in WP 2.5 - ignores category id/name) created
item.dc:creator: TrishaM
item.description:
Used the following code as suggested in the Codex for in_category, however, in all cases regardless of the actual category ID that the post has assigned to it, the second include-file is being served.

`<?php

$post = $wp_query->post;

if (in_category(16)) {

include(TEMPLATEPATH . '/single-cat-16.php'); }

else {

include(TEMPLATEPATH . '/singleproduct.php'); }

?>`
